creator: gorblau

title: Amazon Prime video
content:
Since installing the latest Firefox update I have been unable to view Amazon Prime videos. I keep getting this error message: Digital Rights Error Your web browser is missing a digital rights component.

In your web browser's address bar, type about:addons, press Enter, and then on the left, click Plugins. For the Widevine Content Decryption Module, select Always Activate, and then refresh the video's page and try watching the video.

If the video doesn't play, go back to Plugins, click the gear icon at the top of the page, and then click Check for Updates. When the plugins have updated, refresh the video's page, and then try watching the video.

I had no problems with the previous version of Firefox. I am running in Linux Mint 20.1, Firefox 89.02, 64 bit.

title: Having trouble with Firefox being slow when first starting
content: Ever since version 88 or 89 Firefox has started being slow to load. I have tried everything. Uninstalled it, reinstalled it. Started it in safe mode. Started it without the 4 addons I use. Refreshed it. Started it as a new installation with nothing on it without signing in. People have tried to direct me to troubleshooting and basically threw up their hands and chalked it up to user error. All why Chrome and Brave with all the same settings and addons open immediately and run smoothly with no issues. So I know it’s not user error. There have been a few updates for Firefox but none of them fixed anything. No one has been able to help me fix the issue. I don’t know what it is and have never had this issue before with any browser. It’s slow loading the first time I open it and then works fine afterwards, albeit more slowly than Chrome or Brave. Also, Firefox is installed on my SSD drive in my gaming laptop running more than enough memory and with a Nvidia 1060 with updated drivers.

title: What settings must I use to play video on MSN website
content:
Hi, I use Firefox version 89.0.2 (64-bit).

Video on Youtube plays, Video on Netflix works well, Streaming on Peacock TV works too.

So what's the secret to playing a Video (usually with a news article) on www.msn.com. These videos I am using msn.com, because that's where I sign in to my Outlook.com (online) e-mail. Yes, I am behind the times.

(I would have liked to use Thunderbird, but since it did not work straight out of the box, and there was no advice about things like "proxies, IMAP, POP3, etc" from anyone here at Firefox, I could not make it work, hence stuck with the e-mail system which is constantly renamed by MSFT from MSN, to Hotmail, to live.com, to Outlook, to Outlook.Live.com. As if renaming something would make it better...)

If I knew how, I'd be fine to activate "MS Media Player", or that "VLC player" within Firefox. Reasonable people are ok with finding out which lid fits on which pot, and which screwdriver works with different types of screws.

Why software people cannot appreciate the concept of "for this task, you need this tool", and make it simple and clear to do so, that will forever remain a mystery to me.

So, does anyone here at Firefox have the basic pride of saying to themselves: "There has got to be a way to do this!" and then work the problem until it is solved? For example, why can't I "right-click" on the misbehaving video clip, and get an option "Play video via this or that player"? It can't be that hard, you could even have it in a separate window, if that's required for one of myriads of software reasons no one can ever explain.
creator: voodooquantum

title: How to copy selection to X primary on Linux?

The second mode (copying to X primary), no longer works for me. How can I fix it? (The feature works on other GTK apps)

title: www.mozilla.org uses an invalid security certificate.
content:
Hi, On Mozilla Firefox, while browsing to https://mozilla.org gives this exception

===========================================

Your connection is not secure

The owner of www.mozilla.org has configured their web site improperly. To protect your information from being stolen, Firefox has not connected to this web site.

This site uses HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) to specify that Firefox only connect to it securely. As a result, it is not possible to add an exception for this certificate.

www.mozilla.org uses an invalid security certificate. The certificate is not trusted because it is self-signed. The certificate is not valid for the name www.mozilla.org. The certificate expired on Wednesday, June 23, 2021 4:44 PM. The current time is Wednesday, June 30, 2021 10:26 AM. Error code: SEC_ERROR_UNKNOWN_ISSUER

=========================================

While on browsing on Nightly, https://mozilla.org gives following certificate exception

=========================================

www.mozilla.org uses an invalid security certificate.

The certificate is not trusted because it is self-signed.

Error code: MOZILLA_PKIX_ERROR_SELF_SIGNED_CERT

title: Firefox updated and now only prints thumbnail size
content:
So far as I know, got _most_ of my Firefox settings back to "normal" following an automatic "update" but I am no longer able to properly print from Firefox. [I had to install Chrome to use when I need to print]. Anyway, the print preview shows up as portrait, but the THUMBNAIL-sized image now prints "sideways" or in landscape mode.

The issue of printing thumbnail images [versus full-size] after an update appears to be a somewhat frequent problem in Firefox, [though the posts I have found are all older-- 2014, 2015, 2016...]. Anyway, the problem generally seems to have been "the preference: printer_printer_name.print_paper_data -- being set to 256. Changing the value to 1 solved the paper size problem."

Following the "Fix printing problems" tips from Firefox to find the preferences, I: Clicked the menu button, clicked Help, then selected More Troubleshooting Information. The Troubleshooting Information page with the address about:support opened in a new tab.

When I scrolled down to the Printing section, I found the equivalent "print_paper_data" section, except it is already set to the value 1...

Help!!!!

And yes, Firefox is the only browser with this issue. Am seriously considering removing automatic updating in Firefox-- each update seems to create new problems. And, may finally move to Chrome as it seems to have fewer issues. Don't care for Chrome, but there have been many times when weird things happen following updates, and the only way I can properly access needed work software has sometimes been to use Chrome....
